Additional Assertions for assert_that

Source: R/assertthat.R
assertions.Rd

We provide additional assertion functions which can be used together with assertthat::assert_that().

Usage

is_character_or_factor(x)

is_nonnegative_count(x)

is_variables(x)

is_df_with_variables(df, variables)

is_df_with_factors(df, variables)

is_df_with_nlevels_factor(df, variable, n_levels, relation = c("==", ">="))

is_equal_length(...)

is_proportion(x, include_boundaries = FALSE)

is_proportion_vector(x, include_boundaries = FALSE)

is_quantiles_vector(x, include_boundaries = FALSE)

is_valid_factor(x)

is_factor_no_na(x)

is_valid_character(x)

all_elements_in_ref(x, ref)

has_tabletree_colnames(x, col_names)

is_df_with_no_na_level(df, variables, na_level)

Arguments

x

object to test

df

(data frame)
input dataset.

variables

(named list)
columns from dataset where you want to check if na_level exists.

variable

(string)
name of the single variable.

n_levels

(count)
number of levels to compare with.

relation

(string)
which relational operator to use for the comparison.

...

a collection of objects to test.

include_boundaries

(logical)
whether to include boundaries when testing for proportions.

ref

(vector)
where matches from x are sought for all_elements_in_ref.

col_names

(character)
column names which should be present in the table.

na_level

(string)
the string user has been using to represent NA or missing data.

Value

flag whether the assertion holds (TRUE or FALSE). When used inside assertthat::assert_that() produces a meaningful error message.

Functions

  • is_character_or_factor: Check whether x is a character or factor vector.

  • is_nonnegative_count: Check whether x is a nonnegative count.

  • is_variables: Check whether x is a valid list of variable names.

  • is_df_with_variables: Check whether df is a data frame with the analysis variables.

  • is_df_with_factors: Check whether df is a data frame where the analysis variables are all factors.

  • is_df_with_nlevels_factor: Check whether df is a data frame where the analysis variable is a factor with n_levels number of levels.

  • is_equal_length: Check that objects provided are of same length.

  • is_proportion: Check whether x is a proportion: number between 0 and 1.

  • is_proportion_vector: Check whether x is a vector of proportions (numbers between 0 and 1).

  • is_quantiles_vector: Check whether x is a sorted vector of unique quantile proportions (numbers between 0 and 1).

  • is_valid_factor: Check whether x is a valid factor (has levels and no empty string levels).

  • is_factor_no_na: Check whether NA has been handled when x is a factor.

  • is_valid_character: Check whether x is a valid character (has no NAs and no empty strings).

  • all_elements_in_ref: Check whether all elements of x are in a reference vector.

  • has_tabletree_colnames: Check whether rtables object x has the specified column names.

  • is_df_with_no_na_level: check if the input df has na_level in its variables.

Examples


# Check whether `x` is a character or factor vector.
is_character_or_factor(-1)
#> [1] FALSE
is_character_or_factor(c("a", "b"))
#> [1] TRUE
is_character_or_factor(factor(c("a", "b")))
#> [1] TRUE

# Check whether `x` is a nonnegative count.
is_nonnegative_count(-1)
#> [1] FALSE
is_nonnegative_count(0L)
#> [1] TRUE
is_nonnegative_count(10L)
#> [1] TRUE
is_nonnegative_count(0)
#> [1] TRUE
is_nonnegative_count(10)
#> [1] TRUE

# Check whether `x` is a valid list of variable names.
is_variables(list(val = "a"))
#> [1] TRUE
is_variables(list(val = c("a", "b")))
#> [1] TRUE
is_variables(list(1, 2))
#> [1] FALSE
is_variables(list("bla"))
#> [1] FALSE

# Check whether `df` contains the analysis `variables`.
is_df_with_variables(df = data.frame(a = 5, b = 3), variables = list(val = "a"))
#> [1] TRUE
is_df_with_variables(df = data.frame(a = 5, b = 3), variables = list(val = c("a", "b")))
#> [1] TRUE

# Check whether `df` contains all factor analysis `variables`.
is_df_with_factors(
  df = data.frame(a = factor("A", levels = c("A", "B")), b = 3),
  variables = list(val = "a")
)
#> [1] TRUE

# Check whether `df` contains a factor `variable` with `n_levels` levels.
is_df_with_nlevels_factor(
  df = data.frame(a = factor("A", levels = c("A", "B")), b = 3),
  variable = "a",
  n_levels = 2
)
#> [1] TRUE

#' # Check whether `x` is a valid list of variable names.
a <- 1
b <- NULL
c <- c(1, "car")
d <- 5
is_equal_length(a, b, c, d)
#> [1] FALSE

# Check whether `x` is between 0 and 1.
is_proportion(x = 0.3)
#> [1] TRUE
is_proportion(x = 1.3)
#> [1] FALSE
is_proportion(x = 0, include_boundaries = TRUE)
#> [1] TRUE

# Check whether `x` is a vector of numbers between 0 and 1.
is_proportion_vector(c(0.3, 0.1))
#> [1] TRUE
is_proportion_vector(c(1.3, 0.1))
#> [1] FALSE
is_proportion_vector(0, include_boundaries = TRUE)
#> [1] TRUE

# Check whether `x` is a vector of sorted quantile proportions between 0 and 1.
is_quantiles_vector(c(0.1, 0.3))
#> [1] TRUE
is_quantiles_vector(c(0.3, 0.1))
#> [1] FALSE
is_quantiles_vector(c(0.3, 0.3))
#> [1] FALSE
is_quantiles_vector(0, include_boundaries = TRUE)
#> [1] TRUE

# Check whether `x` is a valid factor.
is_valid_factor(-1)
#> [1] FALSE
is_valid_factor(factor(c("a", "b")))
#> [1] TRUE
is_valid_factor(factor(c("a", "")))
#> [1] FALSE
is_valid_factor(factor())
#> [1] FALSE

# Check whether `NA` has been handled when `x` is a factor.
is_factor_no_na(factor(c("a", NA)))
#> [1] FALSE
is_factor_no_na(factor(c("a", "<Missing>")))
#> [1] TRUE

# Check whether `x` is a valid character vector
is_valid_character(-1)
#> [1] FALSE
is_valid_character(c("a", "b"))
#> [1] TRUE
is_valid_character(c("a", ""))
#> [1] FALSE
is_valid_character("")
#> [1] FALSE

# Check whether all elements of `x` are in a reference vector.
all_elements_in_ref(c("a", "b"), c("a", "b", "c"))
#> [1] TRUE
all_elements_in_ref(c("a", "d"), c("a", "b", "c"))
#> [1] FALSE
all_elements_in_ref(c(1:3), c(1:5))
#> [1] TRUE

df <- data.frame(a = 1:3, b = 2:4)
df$a <- ifelse(df$a == 1, "<Missing>", df$a)
is_df_with_no_na_level(df, variables = list(a = "a"), na_level = "<Missing>")
#> [1] FALSE
is_df_with_no_na_level(df, variables = list(b = "b"), na_level = "<Missing>")
#> [1] TRUE
is_df_with_no_na_level(df, variables = list(a = "a", b = "b"), na_level = "<Missing>")
#> [1] FALSE
